title: 109_hr5005
content: The "Firearms Corrections and Improvements Act" amends age limit provisions for firearm and ammunition sales. It also addresses possession and transfer of machine guns for industry testing and security contracting. The Firearms Corrections and Improvements Act allows federal contractors to possess and use machineguns for national security services or related training, as authorized by the Attorney General. The Firearms Corrections and Improvements Act allows possession of post-86 machineguns for testing, research, development, training, and security purposes, including transfers to comply with contracts for national security services or training, and for licensed manufacturers or importers for testing and research. The Firearms Corrections and Improvements Act allows possession of post-86 machineguns for testing, research, design, development, and training purposes. Transfer of machineguns to another person is restricted unless approved by the Attorney General based on background check information. The Firearms Corrections and Improvements Act allows possession of post-86 machineguns for specific purposes, including testing and training. Importation of machineguns for designated purposes is also addressed in the Act. The Firearms Corrections and Improvements Act allows possession of post-86 machineguns for testing and training purposes. It defines "national security services" as protective, defensive, or security services provided under a contract with a US department or agency. The amendments made by this section will take effect after a 180-day period from the enactment of the Act. The Firearms Corrections and Improvements Act eliminates obsolete language from the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act. It also prohibits the Attorney General from charging any tax or fee for background checks and removes the requirement for written permission for supervised handgun use. Section 922(x)(3)(A) of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow juveniles to possess and use a handgun or ammunition for ranching, farming, target practice, hunting, or firearm instruction without prior written consent if a parent or guardian is present and supervising. In section 922(x)(3)(A) of title 18, United States Code, juveniles are allowed to possess and use a handgun or ammunition for specific purposes without prior written consent if a parent or guardian is present and supervising. Additionally, there are exceptions for individuals prohibited by federal or local law from possessing a firearm. SEC. 7. ELIMINATION OF DUPLICATIVE MULTIPLE SALES REPORT REQUIREMENT. Amends subsection 923(g)(3) of title 18, United States Code to eliminate duplicative sales report requirements. SEC. 8. BAN ON ELECTRONIC RETRIEVAL OF FIREARMS PURCHASER INFORMATION. Amends subsection 923(g)(4) to prohibit the Attorney General from electronically retrieving purchaser information. SEC. 9. TRACE DISCLOSURE. Section 923(g) of title 18, United States Code is amended to restrict the disclosure of information kept by licensees and in the firearms trace system database to law enforcement agencies for criminal investigations only. The information described in subparagraph (A) is immune from legal process, not subject to subpoena or discovery, and not admissible as evidence in civil actions. Testimony relying on this information is also inadmissible in court or administrative proceedings, except those initiated by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives. This subsection does not prevent the disclosure of statistical information on total production. The curr_chunk states the disclosure of statistical information on total production, importation, and exportation by licensed importers and manufacturers. SEC. 10. BARREL AND RECEIVER IMPORTATION. Amends Section 925(e) of title 18, United States Code to allow importation of frames or receivers of rifles, or barrels for firearms other than handguns, for repair or replacement purposes. Amends Section 925(a)(1) to include barrels in governmental imports. Effective date is upon enactment of the Act.
